title: JSON schema for Travis CI configuration files

slackRoom.description: Your account name, token and optional channel

solution.description: When the optional solution key is present, Travis will run NuGet package restore and build the given solution.

podfile.description: By default, Travis CI will assume that your Podfile is in the root of the repository. If this is not the case, you can specify where the Podfile is

brew_packages.description: A list of packages to install via brew. This option is ignored on non-OS X builds.

cran.description: CRAN mirror to use for fetching packages

repos.description: Dictionary of repositories to pass to options(repos)

arch.description: The CPU Architecture to run the job on

os.description: The operating system to run the job on

apt.description: To install packages not included in the default container-based-infrastructure you need to use the APT addon, as sudo apt-get is not available

update.description: To update the list of available packages

sourceline.description: Key-value pairs which will be added to /etc/apt/sources.list

key_url.description: When APT sources require GPG keys, you can specify this with key_url

packages.description: To install packages from the package whitelist before your custom build steps

hosts.description: If your build requires setting up custom hostnames, you can specify a single host or a list of them. Travis CI will automatically setup the hostnames in /etc/hosts for both IPv4 and IPv6.

working_dir.description: If you’d like to upload file from a specific directory, you can change your working directory

debug.description: If you’d like to see more detail about what the artifacts addon is doing

notification_email.description: Where email notification of build analysis results will be sent

build_command.description: The command that will be added as an argument to 'cov-build' to compile your project for analysis

branch_pattern.description: Pattern to match selecting branches that will run analysis. We recommend leaving this set to 'coverity_scan'

quiet.description: Travis CI clones repositories without the quiet flag (-q) by default. Enabling the quiet flag can be useful if you’re trying to avoid log file size limits or even if you just don’t need to include it.

submodules.description: Control whether submodules should be cloned

lfs_skip_smudge.description: Skip fetching the git-lfs files during the initial git clone (equivalent to git lfs smudge --skip),

clone.description: In some work flows, like build stages, it might be beneficial to skip the automatic git clone step.

sparse_checkout.description: Is a path to the existing file in the current repository with data you’d like to put into $GIT_DIR/info/sparse-checkout file of format described in Git documentation.

autocrlf.summary: Specify handling of line endings when cloning repository

tags.description: Tell Travis CI to only deploy on tagged commits

skip_cleanup.description: After your tests ran and before the release, Travis CI will clean up any additional files and changes you made. Maybe that is not what you want, as you might generate some artifacts that are supposed to be released, too.

overwrite.description: If you need to overwrite existing files

oneOf.description: Deploy master branch to heroku app
Deploy the different branch to the different heroku app

run.description: to run a command on Heroku after a successful deploy

skip_cleanup.description: Travis CI default will clean up any additional files and changes you made, you can by it to skip the clean up

strategy.description: Travis CI supports different mechanisms for deploying to Heroku: api is default

source.description: The source to import build config from

mode.description: How to merge the imported config into the target config (defaults to deep_merge_append)

if.description: Specifies a condition for the import

fast_finish.description: If some rows in the build matrix are allowed to fail, the build won’t be marked as finished until they have completed. To mark the build as finished as soon as possible, add fast_finish: true

stage.description: The name of the build stage
The name of the build stage

fast_finish.description: If some rows in the build matrix are allowed to fail, the build won’t be marked as finished until they have completed. To mark the build as finished as soon as possible, add fast_finish: true

stages.description: Specifies the order of build stages

if.description: Specifies a condition for the stage

import.description: Import YAML config snippets that can be shared across repositories.
